It was announced today that David Gilmour will play the first ever seated concert at Rome’s Circus Maximus on 2 & 3 July.  This new ‘Roman’ addition to the Rattle that Lock world tour, follows on from Gilmour’s announcement that his Pompeii concert will create history by being the first rock concert to take place on the site with an audience. Tickets for Circus Maximus will be priced from €60 (subject to booking fees) and will go on sale on Thursday 7 April from www.davidgilmour.com at 10:00hrs CET. Please note tickets will be limited to 4 per person.

This latest world heritage site concert is part of David Gilmour’s aim to play his Rattle That Lock concerts in venues that are beautiful and historic and give the fan a once in a lifetime experience.  Circus Maximus was first constructed in the 6th century BC as a chariot race track, today it is a public park and occasional site for concerts.

Following these two concerts in Rome, David Gilmour will head for Pompeii and play two concerts in its world famous Amphitheatre. About David Gilmour
A reminder: tickets for David Gilmour's return to Pompeii's Roman Amphitheatre on July 7th and 8th, go on sale tomorrow, Tuesday 22 March at 13:00hrs CET from www.DavidGilmour.com. Timeline Photos

Now confirmed: as part of his Rattle That Lock tour, David Gilmour is returning to Pompeii's Roman Amphitheatre on July 7th and 8th, to perform the only attended rock concerts ever to take place on the site. In 1971, Pink Floyd were the first to play the historic venue, recording 'Pink Floyd: Live at Pompeii' in the empty arena. Tickets for the concerts will be on sale on Tuesday 22 March at 13:00hrs CET from www.DavidGilmour.com.

David: "I want to thank the Ministry of Culture for giving me the opportunity to once again play this beautiful and historic venue. Performing there in 1971 was very special and I'm looking forward to returning and hopefully creating some more memorable moments made even more special by playing to an audience."

There are ticket restrictions in place, and full details are on www.DavidGilmour.com. Tickets are limited to a maximum of two per person for one show only (not both), and photographic ID must be shown.

David Gilmour has announced that he will perform live in the UK and Europe in September 2015 to coincide with the release of his, as yet untitled, fourth solo studio album. Tickets go on sale for all venues, detailed below, at 10:00am GMT on Friday 6 March 2015.

It then visits Verona’s amphitheatre, the Verona Arena on 14 September and the Teatro Le Mulina in Florence, Italy on September 15. Nick Mason, on Pink Floyd Live At Pompeii:
“It turned out to be a very useful and, I think, a very good film. It was a controlled environment, as there was no audience, so we could cut, stop and reshoot. But the open air and the dust and everything else made it feel like a real live show. There was a bit of grit to it.”
Guitar World, 2012. Timeline Photos

In a wonderfully rural setting, Pink Floyd's 1989 tour started in Werchter, Belgium. Taking the place of the plane was a flying bed for "On The Run". In the venue was a large tree in the audience area, and in the afternoon before the show, this initially caused problems as the bed - whilst being winched back ready for its flight - got caught up in branches. Timeline Photos
Quite a line-up...looks like it would have been well worth the £1 for the ticket. Timeline Photos

During October 1971, Pink Floyd performed at the Roman amphitheatre in Pompeii, Italy, in front of Adrian Maben's cameras - and no audience. The resulting film, Pink Floyd: Live at Pompeii, came out the following year and is a much loved record of those earlier days. Here's a picture of the band in the atmospheric venue. Timeline Photos

Today sees the worldwide release of Darkside, the play written by Sir Tom Stoppard for BBC Radio 2, incorporating music from Pink Floyd's The Dark Side of the Moon, and aired in the UK at the end of August. The luxury package resembles a hard-backed book, including a CD carrying the 54-minute play, which includes the majority of the Dark Side of the Moon album, plus a 56-page bound insert of the play’s script.

Darkside, the play written by Sir Tom Stoppard for BBC Radio 2, incorporating music from Pink Floyd's The Dark Side of the Moon, and aired in the UK at the end of August, is released worldwide as a deluxe CD package on 25 November 2013.

Produced in collaboration with Sir Tom’s publishers Faber and Faber, the luxury package resembles a hard-backed book, including a CD carrying the 54-minute play, which includes the majority of the Dark Side of the Moon album, plus a 56-page bound insert of the play’s script. The cover features artwork by Hipgnosis designer Aubrey ‘Po’ Powell in collaboration with StormStudios, based on the specially-created Aardman Animations piece used to publicise the broadcast. The full play script includes all the dialogue and stage directions, plus Roger Waters’ original lyrics from the album. The release also features a bonus disc with text translations in German, French, Spanish, Italian, Dutch, Portuguese, Japanese, Mandarin and Russian.

Tom Stoppard said: “When The Dark Side of the Moon was a new album in 1973, a friend of mine walked into my room where I was working with a copy in his hand and said “You really have to do a play about this album.” So, when, roughly 39-and-a-half years later, Jeff Smith from Radio 2 asked me if I’d like to do some kind of play around the 40th birthday of the Pink Floyd album, it really wasn’t a very difficult decision.”

Darkside is an abstract and compelling drama which follows Emily, a philosophy student, through a series of thought experiments, which are vividly brought to life. The play also ranges over a series of grand themes, which are both thought provoking and laced with Stoppard’s characteristic wit and humour. The cast is impressive, with Bill Nighy as Dr Antrobus/the Witch Finder, Rufus Sewell is Mr Baggott/Ethics Man, Adrian Scarborough is Fat Man and Amaka Okafor is Emily. 

David Gilmour: “I found the script of Tom’s play fascinating; I can’t think of a better way to celebrate The Dark Side of The Moon’s 40 year anniversary.”

Nick Mason: “I love it. If anyone is going to mess with the crown jewel of albums, Tom is a very good choice.”

Bill Nighy: “To get a combination of Tom Stoppard and Pink Floyd…is a massive deal, a marriage made in radio heaven.” Timeline Photos

Last night, the Cambridge Corn Exchange saw Syd Barrett's family, friends, and fans all come together for a celebration of the man and his music. The concert featured Swedish band Men on the Border performing Syd's songs, as well as a few of their own, backed by the 50-piece Sandviken Symphony Orchestra. Lighting was provided by Peter Wynne-Willson who worked with Pink Floyd between 1966-1968.

A permanently sited artwork, a memorial to Syd, was also unveiled in the foyer of the Corn Exchange. Timeline Photos

The acclaimed book 'Barrett, the Definitive Visual Companion', is now available at a 25% discount but only until December 8th. Classic Rock called the book "...an essential object for the Syd obsessive", Brain Damage said that it was "absolutely essential", and Mojo Magazine noted that "With the help of the Barrett family and friends, the authors have unearthed a remarkable haul of personal correspondence, previously unpublished photographs and images of all Syd’s known artwork. It's an extraordinary achievement. Beautifully packaged, eruditely written and full of insight, 'Barrett' feels like the ultimate work of art."

You can currently pick up the Classic Edition for £48.75, plus shipping, and the Limited Edition for £225, plus shipping. More details at http://barrettbook.com. Barrett. The definitive visual companion to the life of Syd Barrett. The definitive visual companion to the life of Syd Barrett.

You can now get the informative 1960s Cambridge Music Scene Booklet, created by those who were there, in hard copy. As well as organising walking tours of Cambridge which highlight the places and events of Syd Barrett's early life, Warren Dosanjh, Stephen Pyle, Dave Parker and Tony Middleton edit the I-Spy Syd In Cambridge website, which includes an indepth study of the 1960s music scene in Cambridge, featuring many photos and running to some 72 pages.

The booklet has now been made available to buy as a hi-res printed version with a ring binding. Recently updated, it includes added pages on the Dawnbreakers, the Hi-Fi's, the Prowlers, Clive Welham and Johnny Cullum, as well as photos and stories of other Cambridge musical artists including Those Without, Jokers Wild, and many more.

The price is £15.00, which includes posting & packing in the UK only. Cheques should be made out to 'RCR2' and sent to 14 Greville Road, Cambridge CB1 3QL, accompanied by the name and address of the recipient. Warren Dosanjh advises that it would be helpful for orders to be collected by hand from the above address, if possible.

For countries outside the UK, please contact the site for a price inclusive of posting and packing here: 
http://www.i-spysydincambridge.com/contact Timeline Photos

In 1973, Pink Floyd's The Dark Side of the Moon was released. A rough version of the track Brain Damage was written around the time of Meddle and was actually known as "The Dark Side of the Moon". The 1977 In The Flesh European tour, featuring Animals, was in full swing by this stage in March, and on this day they performed at Wembley's Empire Pool (later renamed Wembley Arena). Pink Floyd started the first of a four-night run at London's Rainbow Theatre (which is now a Brazilian Pentecostal church), on this day in 1972. It was the premiere to the press of the then work-in-progress suite, The Dark Side of the Moon. Timeline Photos

This day in 1972 saw the first attempt to perform The Dark Side of the Moon live. The concert, at the Brighton Dome on the south coast of England, was beset by what Roger Waters called "severe mechanical and electric horror". This resulted in Dark Side being scrapped during Money and some older tracks being hastily brought into the setlist. This picture was taken backstage at the Dome in 1972 by Jill Furmanovsky. Timeline Photos

Ian Emes, who created the celebrated 'flying clocks' sequence in Time for the Dark Side Of The Moon concert screen films, has launched his own exhibition in London, presented as an "immersive installation". Emes also created the 'French Windows' animation based on One Of These Days, and was an advisor on The Wall film. Dark Side Of The Moon - A Photographic Exhibition marks the 40th anniversary of Pink Floyd's first attempted public performance of this album on January 20th 1972 at the Brighton Dome. The exhibition runs from January 20th to March 20th, 2012, at the Founders Room at the Dome, between 10am - 5pm, Tuesday through to Sunday, each week. Admission is free. Photographer Jill Furmanovsky spent considerable time on the road with the band that year, and the exhibition will display a range of her pictures, along with other rare and intimate images by Storm Thorgerson, Colin Prime and Tony Collins.
On the opening evening, there will be a Q&A with Jill, again being hosted in the Founders Room in the Dome. This starts at 7pm, and is also free: Brighton Dome - Dark Side of the Moon Brighton Tickets Celebrating the 40th anniversary of Pink Floyds first performance of this seminal album, which took place on 20th January 1972 at the Brighton Dome. The first of seven shows at the LA Memorial Sports Arena took place today in 1980, bringing Pink Floyd The Wall - with its stunning theatrical presentation, a landmark concert staging - to fans. Timeline Photos

Today in 1968, Pink Floyd appeared at the two-day Flight To Lowlands Paradise festival in Utrecht, The Netherlands. Jimi Hendrix was begged to appear, but couldn't be persuaded, and the Floyd took his place. Here's the colourful poster for that show. Timeline Photos

The final show on the 1967 Jimi Hendrix Winter Tour took place on this day, and included Pink Floyd as one of the bands on the bill. This picture appeared in the programme, and shows the various performers. Can you spot the four members of Pink Floyd in the picture? Timeline Photos

The 1967 Jimi Hendrix Winter Tour was in full swing at this stage in that year. One of the support bands was Pink Floyd, given around 20 minutes in each of the two shows each day (a matinee concert, and an evening concert). Timeline Photos

Today in 1988, Soyuz TM-7 launched, and the Russian cosmonauts took a cassette copy (without the box, to save weight) of Pink Floyd's Delicate Sound of Thunder into space. French president François Mitterrand attended the launch, along with David Gilmour and Nick Mason, who made an audio recording of the event for potential use in a future project. Here's the mission patch... Timeline Photos

Predating the Pompeii filming by a year, Pink Floyd appeared in this Roman Amphitheatre in Frejus, France, in a concert held in 1970. Looks a spectacular place to have seen the band in action. The set would have likely included Astronomy Domine, Atom Heart Mother, Green Is The Colour, Embryo, Set The Controls and more... Timeline Photos
In 1971, Pink Floyd appeared in Japan, performing a number of shows. Here's the band at a press conference: Timeline Photos

Another rescheduled August show, this took place on this day at Manchester City's Maine Road football ground, home to the club for eighty years and briefly used for staging concerts. The band travelled to the city from London, and back again, using the train, much to the surprise of fans doing the same thing! Timeline Photos

One of the Floyd's concerts in 1970 was at the Fillmore West, with a set consisting of Grantchester Meadows, Astronomy Domine, Cymbeline, Atom Heart Mother, The Embryo, Green Is The Colour, Careful With That Axe, Eugene, Set The Controls, and encores of A Saucerful of Secrets and Interstellar Overdrive. Quite a set! Here's the poster for the event... Timeline Photos

In 1967, Pink Floyd played the K4 Discotheque on the (now virtually disappeared into the waves) West Pier in Brighton, England. The set included Astronomy Domine, Interstellar Overdrive, Lucifer Sam and Candy And A Currant Bun, and the band played in front of a 60 foot wide projection screen, which would have been perfect for their light show at the time. Part of their performance was filmed, and the filmmaker reported that the band – and their PA, hung from the ceiling – made the pier shake! A very small bit can be seen in this clip (note: the music may or may not be the Floyd...)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MTzycbTsqPs Psychedelic band in Brighton nightclub. Archive film 92703 Brighton. Nightclub scene. People enter club. Psychedelic scenes. Music from a live band playing.

Today in 1967, the Floral Hall in Belfast was the scene of Pink Floyd's first ever show in Northern Ireland, and included 35mm slides of abstract paintings by a local artist (Cecil McCartney) projected over the band. The venue used to be thriving, but closed in the early to mid-70s. Situated within the grounds of Belfast Zoo, this one-time concert venue – reverberating to the sound of Interstellar Overdrive when the Floyd were there – has more recently been used to store animal food...

At the start of the week, we talked about the first of the 1980 Wall concerts. On this day in 1981, the first of eight concerts in Dortmund took place. The tickets were particularly striking, with a cut-out, brick wall design, as you'll see from this example from the run of shows there... Timeline Photos

Today in 1980, the first of The Wall concerts took place, which (understandably for such complex staging) didn't go without a hitch - during the show, some pyrotechnics set fire to some stage drapes, requiring the show to be temporarily halted while the flames were put out. Timeline Photos

In 1968, Pink Floyd were amongst those on the bill for the Flight To Lowlands Paradise II concert, held at Margriethal-Jaarbeurs, in Utrecht, The Netherlands. The two-day event was delayed from November with the hopes that Jimi Hendrix would participate, but despite this delay Jimi didn't take part. Timeline Photos

Today in 1967 saw the final pair of shows (a matinee and evening show) on the Jimi Hendrix Winter Tour, which included Pink Floyd in support. As they only had 20 minutes allocated to them, the set each night for the Floyd was Take Up Thy Stethoscope and Walk, and Interstellar Overdrive. Timeline Photos

Pink Floyd's Delicate Sound of Thunder became the first rock album to be played in space, when Soviet cosmonauts took the cassette of the album with them on the Soyuz TM-7 which was launched on this day in 1988. David and Nick were both in attendance at the launch, audio of which was recorded for potential future use on a Floyd project. Around this time, this apt image was seen in various places including tour t-shirts. Timeline Photos

The second night of the Jimi Hendrix Winter Tour 1967 took place in Bournemouth on this day with a pair of shows. The tour, which included Pink Floyd alongside The Nice, The Move, Amen Corner, Eire Apparent and Outer Limits, all in support of Jimi's Experience, saw most venues enjoying a matinee and evening show. Timeline Photos
This eye-catching poster for Pink Floyd's 1970 appearance in San Rafael, California, was impossible to miss! Timeline Photos

Concert staging is often basic, more obvious when performers are working during daylight. 45 years ago, the Hyde Park Free Concert took place, and here's a shot of Pink Floyd during their set. Timeline Photos

30 years ago today, Live Aid took place in London and Philadelphia. The concert held on both continents was staged to raise funds for Ethiopian famine relief. Bryan Ferry was one of the performers in London, with a band including Jon Carin on keyboards, and David Gilmour on guitar... Timeline Photos

In 1967 Pink Floyd performed one of their key concerts: Games For May - Space Age Relaxation For The Climate Of Spring. Held at the Queen Elizabeth Hall in London, it was reportedly the first show to use speakers at the rear of the hall to give a quadraphonic, surround sound effect. The show included the band chopping wood on stage, a man dressed as an admiral giving out daffodils, and a bubble machine, the output of which staining the seats and carpets. Timeline Photos

Today in 1988, the Houses of Parliament were overshadowed by the serene sight of a large inflatable bed - a fun promotional event to promote the upcoming UK concerts that year, which took place at London's Wembley Stadium, and Manchester's Maine Road. Timeline Photos

The Bank was the venue for Pink Floyd's 1968 appearance in Torrance, California, during a North American tour. Amongst the tracks performed were Interstellar Overdrive, Astronomy Domine and Let There Be More Light... Timeline Photos

As this poster shows, Pink Floyd appeared at Detroit's Grande Ballroom this day in 1968. It was part of their second North American tour, and the set included pieces such as Astronomy Domine, Interstellar Overdrive, A Saucerful Of Secrets, and Flaming. Timeline Photos
Pink Floyd did a photo-shoot in London's Kew Gardens in 1968. From the range of pictures that came out of the session (and used in various places) this is a slightly less-known shot: Timeline Photos

One of Pink Floyd's key 1967 shows took place today. The Games For May concert at the Queen Elizabeth Hall included the first quadraphonic sound system used in a live setting, a man dressed as an admiral giving out daffodils, the band chopping wood on stage, and bubbles generated from a machine during the show (which ended up staining all the furniture in the hall - resulting in a ban for the group from this venue). This picture shows the band during rehearsals. Timeline Photos

Pink Floyd appeared at Mothers Club in Birmingham, England today in 1969, and BBC Radio 1 DJ John Peel said that the show sounded "like dying galaxies lost in sheer corridors of time and space". Parts of the show were used on the Ummagumma live album, which, if your country has it, can be heard on Spotify: http://open.spotify.com/album/55MYyc2jD5T1YgOUpuwEbf

More Furious Madness from the Massed Gadgets of Auximenes took place on this day in 1969 at the Royal Festival Hall in London, with Pink Floyd enhancing their The Man and The Journey song suites with the Azimuth Co-ordinator, a joystick operated quadraphonic sound system operated by Richard Wright from the stage. The Man and The Journey blended new songs along older ones (albeit under new titles) whilst things like a table being made took place on stage so that the band could be served tea! Timeline Photos
Today in 1988, to publicise the then upcoming UK concerts, Pink Floyd floated an inflatable bed above the River Thames in London, close by the Houses of Parliament. Timeline Photos

Today in 1967, the final night of the Jimi Hendrix UK Winter Tour took place, with the customary pair of shows (a matinee, and a more standard evening show). For the concerts, Pink Floyd were low on the bill and had less than 20 minutes, so their set consisted of Pick Up Thy Stethoscope And Walk, and Interstellar Overdrive. Timeline Photos

Tonight in 1967 the Jimi Hendrix Winter Tour was in full swing, with Pink Floyd as one of Jimi's support bands. For the tour programme, they got the performers all together for a picture. Can you spot Roger, Syd, Nick and Richard in the midst of the others? Timeline Photos

The second of our 'anniversary' posters, was for Pink Floyd's appearance at the launch event for the International Times newspaper. The show took place at London's Roundhouse in 1966, and concert-goers were urged to bring their own "poison, flowers & gass filled balloons" to the show. Timeline Photos
The UFO Festival was held today/tomorrow in 1967 at London's Roundhouse. Pink Floyd appeared over both days, supported by Arthur Brown on the 1st, and The Move on the 2nd… Timeline Photos

With hot dogs and "soft ultra violet lighting" promised, along with the likes of Pink Floyd, Jimi Hendrix, Cream and The Move on the bill, this show being held in the small market town of Spalding, Lincolnshire, on this day in 1967 sounded well worth the £1 entrance fee... Timeline Photos

Pink Floyd appeared at Mothers Club in Birmingham, England today in 1969, and parts of the show were used on the Ummagumma live album. BBC Radio 1 DJ John Peel said that the show sounded "like dying galaxies lost in sheer corridors of time and space". Here's a rare surviving poster from the show: Timeline Photos

In the month of September 1967, Pink Floyd took the opportunity during a break in concerts to visit a funfair at the Tivoli Gardens in Copenhagen, and practiced their shooting skills... Timeline Photos

Another anniversary - today marks 20 years since the release of Pink Floyd's final album, The Division Bell. The band struggled to find a suitable title, considering things like Pow Wow and Down To Earth. Eventually, with the promise of a donation to his favourite charity The Environmental Investigation Agency, the writer Douglas Adams came up with The Division Bell as his suggested title, which the band liked. Timeline Photos

This evening, KOKO, in London's Camden, saw a diverse bill for a truly thought provoking evening of music, film and speech. The evening was part of the Staging A Revolution: I'm With The Banned series of events run by Belarus Free Theatre.

Participants included groups who are banned from performing in their own countries. Joining them was David Gilmour, Jon Carin and Bryan Chambers performing with Boombox in a set which treated the capacity crowd to a rousing Astronomy Domine, In Any Tongue, Wish You Were Here and the title track from the new album, Rattle That Lock. The last song of the night included backing vocals by Polly and other Gilmour family members and friends.  For a selection of pictures taken during the sound check and concert itself, view the gallery here (http://on.fb.me/1GlaSk9) and for more information on the Belarus Free Theatre visit http://www.belarusfreetheatre.com.

In 1984, David Gilmour released the track Love On The Air (co-written with Pete Townshend, who provided the lyrics) as a single. For a limited time, it was also available as a picture disc, shaped as a radio, with David's portrait on the rear (and seen here): Timeline Photos
As you know, David Gilmour is performing a few shows in Europe in September this year. What tracks do you think, or hope, he performs during those concerts? Timeline Photos

Today saw the first of five concerts for David Gilmour in 2002 - three nights in London, and two in Paris. There were some special guests on various nights: Kate Bush, Robert Wyatt and Bob Geldof, as well as the return to the stage of Richard Wright, which thrilled fans in attendance. Timeline Photos

Further to our earlier post regarding David Gilmour's surprise appearance at Bombay Bicycle Club's concert last night, which was the final gig there before demolition, here's a picture of David during Wish You Were Here, alongside BBC's Jack Steadman. Timeline Photos

Pink Floyd first played at Earls Court in May 1973 during the first year that rock bands started appearing there. David Gilmour was invited to  appear at the last performance at the venue last night (Saturday December 13th) by stepping out for two songs with Bombay Bicycle Club. Having given band member Jamie MacColl his first guitar as a young boy he joined them to a rousing reception on lap steel guitar for Rinse Me Down and then took to acoustic guitar and vocals for Wish You Were Here. Bulldozers will now enter the site to raze this famous building to the ground.

A collaboration in 1985 between Nick Mason and 10cc's guitarist Rick Fenn (who still performs with 10cc today) resulted in the album Profiles. The track Lie For A Lie (released as a single) included guest vocalists Maggie Reilly and David Gilmour, both of whom appeared in the promotional video... Timeline Photos

Eight years ago, David Gilmour performed the first of two nights at Venice's Piazza San Marco, concerts that were rescheduled from the previous weekend due to issues with the stage roof. The first show included On The Turning Away, added by David during soundcheck to the surprise of the band who had to hurriedly learn it, and the second show suffered from heavy rain throughout the first half of the show - one thing that cannot be controlled at outdoor concerts! Timeline Photos

Some of you will recall Life In A Northern Town, the debut by Dream Academy, which was co-produced by David Gilmour, as was its accompanying album. Singer and co-composer Nick Laird-Clowes, known to Floyd fans for his contributions to The Division Bell, has announced a remastered collection of Dream Academy's work, The Morning Lasted All Day. 

It features 24 tracks on 2 CDs, including Life In A Northern Town, The Love Parade and previously unreleased tracks, including Living In A War and The Chosen Few, both of which feature David on guitar. Other guest musicians include Johnny Marr and Lindsey Buckingham.

The album will be available from July 29. For more information, click here: http://www.realgonemusic.com/news/2014/6/12/the-dream-academy.html Timeline Photos

Today sees the release of Hendra, by Ben Watt, on CD and download. The album by the former member of Everything But The Girl includes a guest appearance by David Gilmour who adds plangent slide guitar and backing vocals to the track The Levels. Timeline Photos
David Gilmour's North American tour of 2006 started on this date, with a pair of shows at New York's Radio City Music Hall. Did you manage to see any of the shows on this tour? Timeline Photos

David Gilmour performed the first of three nights at London's Royal Festival Hall, on this day 12 years ago. Guests at the shows were Kate Bush, Bob Geldof, Robert Wyatt, and Richard Wright... Timeline Photos

Today we remember Steve O'Rourke, Pink Floyd's manager from 1968 onwards, who passed away ten years ago. At his funeral, David Gilmour performed Fat Old Sun, and then Great Gig In The Sky, joined by Nick Mason and Richard Wright. A keen racing driver, he set up EMKA Racing in 1980 named after EMKA Productions, his management company. Timeline Photos

Nick Mason's 1985 album, Profiles, was released today, a collaboration with Rick Fenn and including guest performances from Mel Collins, Maggie Reilly, and a vocal from David Gilmour on Lie For A Lie. Timeline Photos

The new issue of the UK's Record Collector magazine has a large and absorbing interview with Nick Mason, talking about a range of early Pink Floyd acetates, and his hopes for an Immersion set looking at the early years. There's also an interview with early producer Joe Boyd, and a guide to some of the rarer Pink Floyd vinyl releases, which includes the approximate value of these items. You can purchase the magazine in major UK stores now, or mail order via: http://recordcollectormag.com/issue-detail/417. Timeline Photos
For this concert in 1969, at London's Royal Festival Hall, the Floyd performed two new song suites, The Man and The Journey. Timeline Photos
Fat Old Sun is a track from the band's 1970 album, Atom Heart Mother, and features Richard Wright on keyboards, and David Gilmour performing all other instrumentation... Pink Floyd - Fat Old Sun

In 1969, Pink Floyd performed a superb concert at London's Royal Festival Hall, showcasing their song suites The Man and The Journey. The show was billed "The Massed Gadgets of Auximenes: More Furious Madness From Pink Floyd". Timeline Photos

As part of the show, David Gilmour made a guest appearance, performing on three songs - Wish You Were Here, Too Much Monkey Business, and A Whiter Shade Of Pale. Fansite Brain Damage have reviewed the show, and they have pictures of David and the band in action: David Gilmour performs at the Douglas Adams 60th Birthday Party 11 March 2012 would have been Douglas Adams' 60th Birthday. To help mark tomorrow's 6th anniversary of the release of David Gilmour's album 'On An Island', and his birthday, for 48 hours there is a free download and stream of the track 'A Pocketful Of Stones'. The download becomes available at midnight tonight from David's website, and if you've not heard the track before, we hope you enjoy it. It features Polish classical/jazz musician Leszek Mozdzer on piano, Alasdair Malloy on glass harmonica and David on guitars, percussion, Hammond organ and bass, as well as vocals.

It will be available until 11:59pm GMT (UK time) on Wednesday 7th March. As this picture shows, David Gilmour and Nick Mason felt comfortable in the cockpit of a plane. Maybe inspired by the promo video for Point Me At The Sky, they later learnt to fly, with Nick occasionally taking the controls of the plane when travelling from city to city on the Momentary Lapse tour, and more recently, becoming a helicopter pilot too. On this day in 2007, London's Barbican was the venue for Madcap's Last Laugh, a tribute event to the late Syd Barrett. with profits from the show donated to the mental health charity SANE. Amongst the many performers were Roger Waters in the first half of the show, and David Gilmour, Nick Mason and Richard Wright in the second half. The four page programme for the event is still available to download (as a PDF) from http://www.barbican.org.uk/media/events/5653sydprogfinal.pdf. Timeline Photos

Visitors to London between now and the end of the year will find, in various locations, more than fifty specially designed statues of the character Paddington Bear - including one designed by Nick Mason which uses Wish You Were Here as its inspiration (with his suitcase having various backstage passes affixed), and can be found at the O2 Arena. The bears form The Paddington Trail, a fundraising effort to benefit the NSPCC (National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children) and children's charity Action Medical Research for whom Paddington Bear has been the official mascot for over 35 years.

There will be an auction for the statues and some of the more collectable items. It is hoped that The Paddington Trail and associated activities will raise over £500,000.
http://www.nspcc.org.uk/fighting-for-childhood/news-opinion/join-paddington-trail/?affId=1991357 Timeline Photos

On this day in 2010, Roger Waters and David Gilmour performed together for the Hoping Foundation Benefit Evening, at Kiddington Hall in Oxfordshire, England. A deal was struck between Roger and David so that in return for Roger's appearance at the Benefit, David would guest in one of Roger's then-upcoming Wall shows. Timeline Photos

Pink Floyd can confirm that they are releasing a new album "The Endless River" in October 2014. It is an album of mainly ambient and instrumental music based on the 1993/4 Division Bell sessions which feature David Gilmour, Nick Mason and Richard Wright. The album is produced by David Gilmour with Phil Manzanera, Youth and recording engineer Andy Jackson. Work is still in progress, but more details to come at the end of the Summer.

War Child is working with renowned British artist Tim Wakefield on a project called "Soundwaves" to celebrate and promote the work of iconic musicians. Tim has ten prints of the "Careful With That Axe, Eugene" soundwave image shown here, signed by Nick Mason, and is selling them online in aid of War Child's Children of Syria Appeal. This aims to raise funds for a new project with Syrian children outside of the refugee camps, where thousands of children remain inaccessible to services or too hidden to receive help. All donations to War Child's appeal will be matched pound-for-pound by the UK Government. Also included in this online sale are 19 other pieces of Soundwaves art inspired by the music of Queen, Brian Wilson, Eric Clapton and many more. The sale will run through to January 31st, 2014, and can be found at http://www.indiegogo.com/projects/soundwaves-art. Timeline Photos

In 1970, Music From The Body was released. A collaboration between Roger Waters and Ron Geesin, the album has music from the film of the same name. The album's final track, Give Birth to a Smile, features all four members of Pink Floyd, plus Geesin on piano, although David Gilmour, Nick Mason and Richard Wright are uncredited. Timeline Photos

Rockarchive, the rock photography collective and gallery network, have announced that Nick Mason will be holding a signing at their pop-up gallery in Monmouth St, WC2 on Thursday 30th May, between 5 and 6pm.

Nick will be visiting the Rockarchive pop-up shop to sign an edition of 50 exclusive photographic prints of himself, made specially for the occasion and available at a reduced price of £100 for the night only. Pink Floyd fans are also invited to bring along one item of personal Pink Floyd memorabilia that they wish to be autographed. On display will also be an extensive collection of Pink Floyd prints displayed in the gallery, plus there will be the chance to enter a raffle to win a signed pair of Nick’s drum sticks.

All prints displayed at the Rockarchive Pop-up Gallery are being sold at a 20% discount for the evening.

Address is: Rockarchive Pop Up Gallery, 46 Monmouth Street, Seven Dials, London WC2H 9EP. The gallery is open every day from 11am – 7pm until Monday 3rd June 2013.

Rockarchive's online site is at www.rockarchive.com. Timeline Photos

Today in 1987 saw the UK single release of On The Turning Away. The UK single came in a variety of formats – standard 7", 12" and CD single versions were joined by a limited 7" in bright pink vinyl. The single was backed by a live version of Run Like Hell. Here's the promotional record store display – made from thick card, it was designed to dangle from the ceiling or other high point in the shop. Timeline Photos

The US release of Pink Floyd's A Nice Pair came out today in 1973. To cope with the very small dimensions of the tape cassette format, just one image was selected from the multiple pictures and visual puns shown on the gatefold cover. Timeline Photos

In 1981, the planned release of Money/Let There Be More Light as a single was cancelled at the last minute. Promotional 7" and 12" copies in pink vinyl were pressed up and are popular with collectors... Timeline Photos

On Friday, a special limited edition set of two 7" singles was released, featuring previously unreleased Pink Floyd tracks. There were just over 1000 of these sets available. "Pink Floyd 1965 – Their First Recordings" included Lucy Leave, Double O Bo, Remember Me, Walk With Me Sydney, Butterfly and I'm A King Bee.

If you weren't one of the lucky ones to come across one of these in your local record store (the only place they were available from), don't worry, Pink Floyd hope to make them available in some physical form towards the end of next year. Timeline Photos

In 1971 Meddle was released. The cover proved unusual as it included a band shot in the centre of the gatefold sleeve - portraits of the band were something neither the Floyd, nor Storm Thorgerson, were particularly keen on. Here is the back of the rare Swiss release, which adapted the band shot to fit onto the single 12 inch square rear of the cover. Timeline Photos

Today in 2001, the compilation Echoes - The Best of Pink Floyd was released, and spanned their career from first single, through to High Hopes, the final track of The Division Bell. In 1992, Pink Floyd released Shine On, a box set of a number of the band's albums, coupled with a CD of their early singles, and a 112-page book unavailable elsewhere. The cover included an image (shown here) which incorporated the album titles, along with the original name for the box set. Do you know what it was going to be called? Timeline Photos

Pink Floyd Records have completed the reintroduction of the Pink Floyd studio albums on vinyl with 'The Final Cut' and 'A Momentary Lapse of Reason' remastered and reissued, available from retailers now. These albums have not been available on vinyl for well over two decades. Over the past year, Pink Floyd Records has released the entire studio collection as stereo remastered versions on heavyweight 180g vinyl. All are mastered from the original analogue studio tapes with album artwork faithfully reproduced.

Released originally in 1983, 'The Final Cut' was another global chart-topper for Pink Floyd. During the Falklands War and the era of Thatcherism, this anti-war concept album explored the themes of fallen servicemen, the loss of loved ones and political betrayal. 

'A Momentary Lapse of Reason', Pink Floyd's thirteenth studio album, was released in 1987 and demonstrated a significant change in style for the band with more experimental use of drum machines and samples. The album also saw the return of graphic artist Storm Thorgerson who designed this now iconic cover.

There's been some discussion over the Seabirds track on The Early Years box set, from reviewers who have an early version of the collection. When the More movie soundtrack work was completed, the tapes of the tracks to be used went to the film company, so the high quality full vocal version of Seabirds is now sadly lost. On the box set are tracks not used in the film, and therefore kept in the archives. One of those tracks - an instrumental also called Seabirds - is included on the set and has never been heard before.

On 18th November 2016, Pink Floyd Records will continue the reintroduction of the Pink Floyd catalogue on vinyl with 'Animals' remastered from the original analogue master tapes and reissued on vinyl for the first time in over 20 years. 'Wish You Were Here' and 'The Dark Side of the Moon' are also back in stock on vinyl from October 14th and November 4th respectively.

These albums began the band’s most successful run of releases, gaining them a whole new audience around the world as their musical style progressed and they toured extensively.

On this day, 48 years ago, Pink Floyd released their second album, A Saucerful of Secrets. In 1983, this US only release was issued. Much to the surprise of fans, it included the early concert favourite Embryo - a track which was played extensively in concert between 1970-71, and when played live, lasted between 12-25 minutes. It was previously only available on a sampler album called Picnic - A Breath of Fresh Air, which included the track without the band's knowledge or approval. Timeline Photos

Released today are the first four albums on vinyl from Pink Floyd Records: ‘The Piper at the Gates of Dawn’, ‘A Saucerful of Secrets’, the soundtrack from the film ‘More’ and the 2 LP set ‘Ummagumma’. The reintroduction of these makes them available on vinyl for the first time in over two decades.

Special care has been taken to replicate the original packaging, and the first batch of releases, mastered by James Guthrie, Joel Plante and Bernie Grundman, will be pressed on 180gram vinyl for optimum sound quality.

Pink Floyd Records will release further titles from the vinyl catalogue throughout the year, with release dates being announced at regular intervals.

In the meantime, are you getting any of these first four, and if so, what are you most looking forward to with these albums?

A Saucerful Of Secrets

The band’s second album, originally released in 1968, was the first album to feature David Gilmour, who replaced Syd Barrett on guitar and vocals. It is both the last Pink Floyd album on which Syd Barrett appeared and the only studio album to which all five band members contributed. This is Pink Floyd in transition from Barrett's psychedelic whimsy to the style of their epic pieces. Classic tracks include Jugband Blues and Set The Controls For The Heart Of The Sun...

Special care has been taken to replicate the original packaging, and the first batch of releases, mastered by James Guthrie, Joel Plante and Bernie Grundman, will be pressed on 180gram vinyl for optimum sound quality.

The soundtrack album to the Raymond Brigg's film, When The Wind Blows, was released in the UK on this day in 1986. Alongside songs for the project written and performed by the likes of David Bowie and Squeeze, were ten new tracks by Roger Waters including the concluding track, Folded Flags. Timeline Photos
This track, The Narrow Way part 3, is our final excerpt from Ummagumma's studio album. This is one of David's tracks. The Narrow Way, part 3

This is an excerpt of Several Species of Small Furry Animals Gathered Together in a Cave and Grooving with a Pict, one of two tracks Roger provided for the studio album of Ummagumma, the other being the better known Grantchester Meadows. Several Species of Small Furry Animals Gathered Together...

The Grand Vizier's Garden Party is from the studio album of Ummagumma. Half the album consists of live tracks, and the other half is split into four - for each band member to do their own material. This is part of Nick's contribution, with the track performed by him, along with Lindy Mason on flute. The Grand Vizier's Garden Party
"Paranoid Eyes" is from Pink Floyd's 1983 album, The Final Cut. Paranoid Eyes

"She'll be selling ………….. on a Sunday afternoon."
A Saucerful of Secrets, Pink Floyd's second album, was released today in 1968. Here's a part of the title track: A Saucerful Of Secrets

"Welcome to the machine..." The track Wish You Were Here took little time in getting one million streams, and so, as promised, Pink Floyd's catalogue (including the recent, expanded Experience editions of The Dark Side Of The Moon, Wish You Were Here, and The Wall) is now available to stream on Spotify. If you've yet to experience this online service, visit www.spotify.com for more information. Timeline Photos

"Tear down the wall!" We're ticking away the moments to the millionth stream of Wish You Were Here on Spotify, which will then unlock the whole Pink Floyd catalogue. Click here to participate: http://spoti.fi/WishUWereHere Timeline Photos

"A million bright ambassadors..." Pink Floyd's entire catalogue will be unlocked on Spotify once Wish You Were Here has been streamed one million times.

Today we mark the release, in 1969, of 'Soundtrack from the film More'. One of a few soundtracks the Floyd recorded during that era, it spawned a few live favourites, such as Green Is The Colour and Cymbaline (which we posted an excerpt from yesterday). Timeline Photos

Grantchester Meadows was a live favourite in 1969/1970, forming part of The Man and The Journey song suites. Pink Floyd - Grantchester Meadows Grantchester Meadows is a song from the 1969 Pink Floyd album Ummagumma.

Today marks the 36th anniversary of the release of Pink Floyd's Animals. This was a slightly unexpected, but certainly eyecatching advert for the album in the UK's New Musical Express weekly newspaper. Timeline Photos
This is a publicity shot for Pink Floyd's 1979 album, The Wall... Timeline Photos
One of the tracks found on the studio disc of Ummagumma is Roger's Grantchester Meadows... Pink Floyd - Grantchester Meadows Grantchester Meadows is a song from the 1969 Pink Floyd album Ummagumma.
Today marks the anniversary of the 1971 release of Pink Floyd's album, Meddle. One of the key tracks, of course, is the side-long Echoes... Timeline Photos

Pink Floyd released Let There Be More Light/Remember A Day as their fourth US single today in 1968. As with their previous singles, it failed to trouble the singles chart... Pink Floyd This is the opening track of the band's second album, A Saucerful Of Secrets, released in 1968.

A Saucerful Of Secrets was released today in 1968, in the UK. It was the only Floyd album to include both Syd Barrett and David Gilmour (other than compilation albums), and saw Pink Floyd as only the second EMI artist (after The Beatles) to employ their own cover artists. Timeline Photos
Cymbaline is one of the tracks from More, released today in 1969. The track became a live favourite during that era. Pink Floyd - Cymbaline

In September, the Pink Floyd Discovery Box Set was released, bringing together all of the band's studio albums together with an exclusive 60-page book designed by Storm Thorgerson, all housed in a specially designed box. The following video gives a full walkthrough of the contents of this box set... Pink Floyd - Discovery Box Set Product Walkthrough Trailer for Pink Floyd's Discovery Box Set - all 14 newly remastered Discovery studio albums available as a boxset collection that also includes an exclusive...
This is the opening track of the band's second album, A Saucerful Of Secrets, released in 1968. Pink Floyd - Let There Be More Light
Pink Floyd's 1994 tour started today in Miami, Florida. Were you there, or did you attend any other shows on that tour? Pink Floyd - Coming Back To Life

I'm creeping back to life
My nervous system all awry
I'm wearing the inside out...
This track is taken from The Final Cut, which celebrated the anniversary of its release yesterday. Pink Floyd - Your Possible Pasts
The Final Cut, the last Pink Floyd album to include Roger Waters, was released on this day in 1983. Timeline Photos

You better make your make your face up in your favourite disguise
With your button-down lips and your roller blind eyes... Pink Floyd - Run Like Hell
Nobody Home appears on Pink Floyd's 1979 album The Wall. Pink Floyd - Nobody Home

To coincide with the release of Animals, the Floyd started their 1977 tour on this day. Here's the poster, featuring the portraits from Meddle rather than any of the then new album's imagery: Timeline Photos
December was a good month for Pink Floyd concerts - and here's a nicely designed poster for one of them: Zurich, 1972. Timeline Photos

Pink Floyd concluded their 1994 World Tour with a set of concerts in October at London's Earls Court, with proceeds from each night going towards a range of charities selected by the band. This picture (photographer unknown) shows the striking frontage of the venue for the shows. Timeline Photos

This rare advert is for the Floyd's 1972 concert at the Hollywood Bowl. The iconic venue inspired the 1994 tour's stage design, and more recently, David Gilmour appeared there as part of his Rattle That Lock World Tour. Timeline Photos

A return to the Werchter Festival Ground for the band, having last played there in 1989, kicking off that year's European tour with a rousing version of Astronomy Domine. Were any of you there? Timeline Photos

The Division Bell tour of 1994 was a major endeavour: 33 trucks carried the stage, there were 11 tour buses, with 16 trucks for production, catering and power. No less than 600 aircraft landing lights were used at the foot of the stage – these revolved at a key part of the show, an effect that Guy Pratt called "Satan's combine harvester"!

With an audience on site of over 200,000, and an estimated worldwide audience of 100 million, courtesy of a live broadcast to more than 20 countries, Pink Floyd's 1989 concert in the lagoon in Venice proved an incredible spectacle... Timeline Photos
Here's the first of two Live 8 rehearsal pictures from June 2005... Timeline Photos
There were two notable posters for Pink Floyd's pair of concerts at the Chateau de Versailles in France, 28 years ago - this one was before the second night was added... Timeline Photos

Advance tickets for Pink Floyd's concert on this day in 1977 were $10.60, and on sale at various record stores and other outlets in the Chicago area. There was some suspicion generally over the number of tickets sold though for this show - officially 67,000, but the band hired a helicopter to take pictures of the crowd to do a head count, which gave a figure closer to 95,000... Timeline Photos
Twenty-eight years ago...were you at this show? Timeline Photos

Today in June 1981, Pink Floyd were half way through a run of five sold-out nights presenting The Wall at London's Earls Court. Due to the logistics of staging, and touring, the show, it was only performed 31 times, in just four cities - London, New York, Los Angeles and Dortmund. Timeline Photos
Twenty-two years ago today, Pink Floyd performed the second of two nights at New York's Yankee Stadium. Did you see the band during their extensive tour that year? Timeline Photos

In 1989, Pink Floyd started their European tour at the Festival Ground in Werchter, in Belgium. With a large tree in the middle of the audience area, it had a different feeling to many of the shows on the tour, and also caused problems during the set-up of the show, with one key element of the show getting caught up in the branches during the afternoon... Timeline Photos
A concert described as "space age relaxation for the climax of spring – electronic composition, colour and image projection, girls, and the Pink Floyd"...today in 1967. Timeline Photos
One of the best loved Pink Floyd concert posters - this one for the two nights in Oakland, 1977... Timeline Photos
A striking if slightly unusual image for a Pink Floyd concert poster... Timeline Photos

"Even the flying pig got soaked..." Today in 1988, Pink Floyd played the Florida Citrus Bowl in Orlando, Florida, but the weather was against them, with a heavy rain storm hitting the show – hard. Here's a local news report on the concert, and the weather conditions which tried (and failed) to dampen the audience's spirits: http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1988-05-02/lifestyle/0030440211_1_pink-floyd-circular-screen-floyd-music. Timeline Photos

On this day in 1968, Pink Floyd played the Piper Club in Rome, Italy – an unusual venue in that it was situated in a cave, with a long staircase to access it... here's a picture of the venue: Timeline Photos
Astronomy Domine was the surprise (and welcome) choice of song that started the 1994 Division Bell tour on this day, at the Joe Robbie Stadium in Miami, Florida... Timeline Photos
Here's the striking 1988 poster for Pink Floyd's Tokyo concerts... Timeline Photos

Today in 1977, Pink Floyd kicked off their In The Flesh World Tour, with the first of two shows in Dortmund. Curiously, the poster for the initial dates used a significantly earlier picture of the band... Timeline Photos
Making their first visit to New Zealand since 1973, Pink Floyd played in Auckland on this day in 1988 as part of their world tour. Timeline Photos
This poster for an early Pink Floyd show gives a good indication to potential attendees of the visual nature of the band's performances... Timeline Photos

In 1966, Pink Floyd performed the Art School Psychedelic Freak Out concert at Cambridge's College of Art and Technology, and here's the poster, showing how the original date of the gig changed (or was misprinted). Timeline Photos

The 1974 Winter Tour was heading toward its conclusion with a pair of shows at the Bristol Hippodrome on this day today/tomorrow. The tour programme was in the form of a children's comic, with the Floyd appearing separately in various stories. Here's the cover of the programme, a bargain at just 15p. Timeline Photos

The 1977 Animals tour of North America took in a number of outdoor venues. To help cope with the varying weather, special "umbrellas" were constructed that could rise and open over the stage as required, and this picture shows them open, shading the band during the soundcheck at one venue. Timeline Photos

On November 21st and 22nd 1970, Pink Floyd played at the Altes Casino in Montreux, Switzerland – the subject of Deep Purple's Smoke On The Water. Here's the poster for the event, which erroneously lists 'Sid' Barrett as still a member of the band. Timeline Photos
The 1994 Division Bell tour featured a stage inspired by the Hollywood Bowl in Los Angeles, California. Here's an unusual shot from behind the stage, in Bordeaux, France. Timeline Photos
In November 1987, Pink Floyd were in the midst of touring. Here's one of the designs which appeared on the t-shirts available from the shows: Timeline Photos
The Fillmore Auditorium in San Francisco saw Pink Floyd playing on this date in 1967. As the poster shows, they were sharing the billing with Procol Harum and HP Lovecraft. Timeline Photos

In 1994, Pink Floyd performed their final ever full length concert, with a show concluding a fifteen night run at London's Earls Court. All the profits from the fifteen concerts went to a selection of 13 charities picked by the band themselves, which included Amnesty International and Greenpeace. Timeline Photos

The second of three days of the Rugby Bag Blues Festival took place today in 1969, with Pink Floyd playing alongside acts such as The Nice, King Crimson, and Free. Hells Angels policed the event, which was beset by bouts of very heavy rain. Timeline Photos

As part of the 2011 launch of Pink Floyd's Discovery, Experience, and Immersion editions of the back catalogue, as well as an inflatable pig once more patrolling the skies above London's Battersea Power Station, the Capitol Records building in Los Angeles was also topped by one. The antenna on the building's roof has a blinking light for aircraft; normally it spells out the word HOLLYWOOD in Morse Code, but for the occasion, it was changed to spell out PINKFLOYD... Timeline Photos
From 1988, here's a scarce poster for the Oslo concert, originally scheduled for this day, but moved to August 2nd. Timeline Photos
One of Pink Floyd's more recognised, early concert posters. This is from the Sacramento shows in 1968... Timeline Photos
This rare flyer advertised Pink Floyd's first ever Australian concert. Have you ever seen them in that country? Timeline Photos
Today saw the second of what turned into three shows in Seattle, 1968, despite the poster just showing two performances... Timeline Photos
On this day in 1968, Pink Floyd played at San Francisco's Avalon Ballroom. The poster for the show didn't make it easy for possible attendees with the text being quite hard to read... Timeline Photos

Another notable 70s Floyd concert - the final night of the 1977 "In The Flesh" tour (that phrase to return for The Wall, of course). This show in Montreal has a much-loved poster, but was just as notable for Roger's reaction to an over-eager fan, which provided the foundations for the band's 1979 album... Timeline Photos

In 1989, Pink Floyd played the first of what quickly became six nights at the London Arena in the Docklands area, when the advertised four nights sold out. The first night was for charity, and the final show was - unusually - an afternoon show, to help with moving the production to The Netherlands for the concert following these London gigs. Timeline Photos

In 1988, Pink Floyd performed at the historic Place d'Armes at the Chateau de Versailles in France. To commemorate the show, a very limited edition, white vinyl Momentary Lapse was sold, with a special poster included within the package. Timeline Photos
On this day in 1989 Pink Floyd were in the midst of their Another Lapse tour, playing the second of a pair of concerts in Livorno, Italy. Here's the cover of the tour programme: Timeline Photos

In 1973, the Floyd played the first of two nights at London's Earls Court (a venue now being demolished for housing) in aid of the National Campaign for the Homeless, with all profits going to the charity Shelter. This poster shows them onstage during that concert. Timeline Photos
At this stage in April 1977, the In The Flesh tour (showcasing the new album, Animals) had resumed, with dates in North America. Here's Roger Waters during that tour. Timeline Photos
Here's another poster from the 1988 tour, for the Sacramento and Oakland shows.  April was often a busy touring month for the Floyd. Timeline Photos

With a live career spanning decades, we suspect a number of you were fortunate enough to have seen Pink Floyd in concert. If you did, what show(s) did you see, and what do you remember most vividly or fondly? Timeline Photos

The 1994 Division Bell tour started today at the Joe Robbie Stadium in Miami, Florida. Three stages leapfrogged around North America and Europe, each 180 feet (55m) long and featuring a 130-foot (40m) arch resembling the Hollywood Bowl venue. All in all, the tour required 700 tons of steel carried by 53 articulated trucks, with a crew of 161 people. This tour played to 5.5 million people in 68 cities. Timeline Photos
The first night of Dortmund's 1981 Wall concerts took part on this day, as this poster advertising the event reveals. Timeline Photos

In 1967, the band performed a concert billed as "Music in Colour by the Pink Floyd" at London's Commonwealth Institute. The concert poster, here, lacked the sort of colour that the audience would have enjoyed... Timeline Photos

Today in 1971, the Floyd played the second of two nights at Hakone Aphrodite 71, Fuji-Hakone-Izu National Park, Hakone, Japan as part of their first tour of that country. The guide to the venue was in cartoon style... Timeline Photos

Today in 1967, Pink Floyd were in the midst of a short tour of Scotland. They performed at the Two Red Shoes Ballroom in Elgin, and this advert for the show promises a "group that brings its own lighting to set the scene oscilating and vibrating with Way Out Sets"... Timeline Photos

Today marks the 25th anniversary of Pink Floyd's concert in Venice. The 1989 concert, on the Canal di San Marco, was performed on a floating stage. It was broadcast live on TV to over 20 countries with an estimated audience of almost 100 million. Did you watch this show, in Venice or at home? Timeline Photos

Today in 1988, Pink Floyd performed the first of two nights at the Chateau de Versailles, in France. A spectacular show, it featured a firework display over the Chateau itself at the conclusion of the concert. There was a French-only special tour edition of A Momentary Lapse of Reason pressed on white vinyl with a Versailles 1988 poster. 

Here’s the concert poster: Timeline Photos

Today in 1977, Pink Floyd performed at Chicago’s Soldier Field. The poster shows the name of the tour that year - In The Flesh - which Roger Waters used in the project that was to follow: The Wall. Timeline Photos

Today in 1969, Pink Floyd performed at the Brighton Dome along with “their Azimuth Co-ordinator” which drove their quadrophonic surround effects during the show. The venue, once the stables for the adjacent Royal Pavilion, proved a favourite on the south coast for the band, who performed there a few times, most notably at the (ill-fated) start of the 1972 tour of The Dark Side of the Moon where the first public performance of the work only got as far as the start of Money… Timeline Photos
Pink Floyd were in the middle of a five night run at Bol Saja Sportivnaja Arena, Lushniki, in Moscow, Russia, on this day in 1989. Here’s one of the posters created for these shows: Timeline Photos

The 1989 European tour was in full swing by this stage in May - on this day that year, they performed the second of two nights in Livorno, Italy. The tour programme (as well as the concert posters and tickets) all had variations on the theme of the "lightbulb man". Timeline Photos

This striking poster promoted a show at the Terrace Ballroom in Salt Lake City, in 1970. We presume that the artist hadn't heard their music prior to designing the poster, perhaps being more suited to a heavy rock band. Timeline Photos

Even at $12.50, this ticket to see Pink Floyd in the Los Angeles area in 1977 on their In The Flesh tour does seem a bargain, but clearly an incentive of $3 off was felt in order for those who bought their ticket early... Timeline Photos

A band that makes heavenly music? Maybe that was the inspiration behind the poster for the Floyd's show today in 1972 at the John F Kennedy Center for Performing Arts, in Washington DC. Timeline Photos
This image promoted the Sacramento concert, and the subsequent pair of shows at the Oakland Stadium, in 1988... Timeline Photos
This slightly bizarre poster advertised the 1994 San Antonio concert - particularly odd as the pig used in the concerts was most definitely male... Timeline Photos
The 1994 Division Bell tour started on this day, with a show in Miami, Florida, in the USA. In total, the tour performed to 5.5 million people in 68 cities. Timeline Photos

In 2000, official recordings of the original Wall concerts were released as Is There Anybody Out There? The start of the concert featured the surrogate band wearing "lifemasks" of Roger, David, Richard and Nick, and the packaging of this release included pictures of these rather eerie masks. Timeline Photos

Our final concert poster - for now. This one isn't quite so easy on the eye. It's advertising Reading University's RagBall in 1969, with the Floyd supported by the Pretty Things, and also offered folk singing, coffee and snacks, and noted that the event was "dress optional"! Timeline Photos

Earlier this week, we talked about the Floyd's 1988 concerts in Japan. This time of year was obviously good for them to visit that country, as in 1972, they were performing there too - as this poster shows. Timeline Photos
At this stage in 1988, Pink Floyd were in the midst of the Japanese leg of their world tour. This rather nice poster was created for that country's concerts. Timeline Photos
The 1988 tour arrived in Tokyo, Japan, for the first of two nights, on this day. Here's the poster advertising the dates: Timeline Photos
In 1995, Pink Floyd's Marooned won a Grammy Award at the Shrine Auditorium in Los Angeles. Timeline Photos
The 1971 European tour was in full swing by this point in February, and this evening saw a show taking place in Offenbach, Germany. Timeline Photos

One of the more interesting posters from 1971 is for the Floyd's show in Farnborough, Hampshire. It features The Mekon, a character in the Dan Dare comic strip. Which Pink Floyd song mentions Dan Dare? Timeline Photos
This rare poster advertises an early 1967 concert Pink Floyd held in Brighton, on the south coast of England. Timeline Photos

The Wall tour of 1980 started on this day at the Los Angeles Memorial Sports Arena. The first night didn't go as smoothly as planned - some pyrotechnics set fire to some curtains, forcing the band to temporarily halt the show. Timeline Photos

Today in 1977, to coincide with the release of the album Animals, the In The Flesh World Tour kicked off in Dortmund, Germany. Here was the poster, advertising the first few shows on that tour... Timeline Photos

This day in 1994, Pink Floyd performed the last of fifteen nights at London's Earls Court. This turned out to be the final full-length Pink Floyd concert, with the band not performing together again until 2005's Live8, where Roger Waters rejoined them. Timeline Photos
The last of our 'anniversary' concert posters (for now) as we remember the 1971 concert at San Diego's Community Concourse. Tickets for the show were priced at $3, $3.50 and $4. Timeline Photos
We have three interesting early Pink Floyd posters for you this week. The first is from 1966, and is for one of their formative shows at the All Saints Hall in London's Powis Gardens. Timeline Photos

Today in 1987, Pink Floyd performed at the Rosemont Horizon, in Chicago, as the eleventh show on the Momentary Lapse tour that year. Those initial shows all started with Echoes, but this show in Chicago saw the final performance of the track, with Shine On taking over as opener for all subsequent shows. The tour programme, shown here, featured a gatefold cover with the 'beds on the beach' imagery. Timeline Photos

Pink Floyd played its last "college show" in the US at George Washington University's Lisner Auditorium in Washington DC in the autumn of 1971. While the band may have physically left the university scene, their music and their legend never did; their presence remain as strong as ever on campuses everywhere today, with Pink Floyd memorabilia adorning dorm rooms worldwide. The third of our August 1968 US posters for you - this time, it was for the first of two nights at The Bank, in Torrance, CA. Timeline Photos
People in Sacramento couldn't fail to notice the poster for Pink Floyd's 1968 concert in the city... Timeline Photos

Pink Floyd's first Australian tour kicked off today in 1971. 1968 saw some very eye-catching posters for Pink Floyd concerts. This one was created for the Avalon Ballroom concert on this day, and with its complex font, was sure to have given San Francisco residents a hard time deciphering it! Timeline Photos
As part of their 1994 European tour, Pink Floyd played the second of two nights at the historic Chateau de Chantilly, in France, on this day. Here's the poster advertising the show: Timeline Photos
In 1970, Pink Floyd played in Aachen, West Germany, at the 1st Open Air Pop Festival, alongside other bands such as Deep Purple, Traffic and Golden Earring. Timeline Photos

Today in 1977, Pink Floyd played their infamous concert in Montreal which concluded their In The Flesh tour - and gave Roger the inspiration he needed for The Wall. Here's the much loved poster: Timeline Photos
This poster is one of the best-loved ones from Pink Floyd's 1977 tour, and advertises the pair of shows they played at the Californian venue. Timeline Photos

Today in 1980, Pink Floyd started the quite limited tour of The Wall, with a night at the Los Angeles Sports Arena, affected by the small matter of a stage curtain catching fire due to some errant pyrotechnics... Timeline Photos

Pink Floyd's final run of concerts on the 1994 tour started on this day, at London's Earls Court running until October 29th, with proceeds from the concerts going to a selection of charities. The opening night show at Earls Court was shortlived, though, after a section of seating collapsed. No-one was seriously injured, although eight people were taken to hospital for treatment. This poster advertises the first of the shows to be announced. Timeline Photos
On this day, Pink Floyd played the second of two nights at the then new venue The Bank in Torrance, California, which also marked the end of their 1968 US tour. Timeline Photos
Getting ready for tonight's show in Quebec, to conclude the 2012 tour. [Photo: Renaud Philippe] Timeline Photos

Pink Floyd on the Canal di San Marco, Venice, performing on a floating stage. The 1989 concert was broadcast live on TV to over 20 countries with an estimated audience of almost 100 million. Timeline Photos

During their In The Flesh tour of 1977, presenting Animals along with other material, Pink Floyd performed at Soldier Field in Chicago. The concert poster for this show is one of the nicer examples from that year... Timeline Photos
Green Is The Colour became a live favourite during Pink Floyd's concerts in 1969/1970. Pink Floyd - Green Is The Colour

Pink Floyd's 1977 Animals tour arrived in Miami on April 22nd. The staging included a number of inflatables, including this one. Did you manage to see the band on this tour, in Europe or North America? Timeline Photos

Pink Floyd played the first of two nights at Rome's Piper Club, today in 1968. The venue was a cave, accessible only by a long staircase. On this day in 1980, Pink Floyd's The Wall tour started at the Memorial Sports Arena, Los Angeles. The first show had its problems; at one point, the show was stopped due to pyrotechnics setting fire to stage curtains. Timeline Photos
